The Editor
The Washington Post
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
The Post's editorial on May 14, endorsing the main principles
of the Public Television Act will add important support to
this unique legislation. However, it misses the opportunity
to reinforce the Senate Commerce Committee's amendment of the
bill calling for a Public Broadcasting concept.
The Senate Committee's change in the title of the bill and
the name of the Public Corporation recognizes that radio and
television should be seen as complementary resources that must
both be used fully to meet the varied educational, cultural,
and social demands of our society.
The Senate bill, as amended, corrects the inappropriate
omission of radio and the potential for educational broadÂ¬
casting to serve through both its media is considerably
enhanced by the conceptual implications of their amendments.
Both the problems and the promise that the Post anticipates
for television also relate to radio, not because the media
are identical, but because together they represent a total
potential for service that can not be fulfilled by either
one alone.
Sincerely yours.
WGH:mab
William G. Harley
President
